abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Structural
            Adjustment Loan (SAL) Project is to assist the government in
            undertaking structural reforms necessary to lay the
            foundation for renewed economic growth and to maintain
            macroeconomic stabilization over the medium term; and to
            finance an adequate level of pubic services during the
            fiscal transition from a centrally planned economy to a
            market-oriented economy. Provided that the government
            demonstrated its commitment to accelerate the pace of
            structural reform, the Bank will provide an accelerated
            program of policy advice, fast-disbursing adjustment
            lending, and project financing in support of high priority
            public and private sector investments over the next two
            years. This lending will include the present structural
            adjustment loan, which is closely coordinated with the
            IMF's Extended Fund Facility (EFF) program, to address
            key reforms in private sector development, specifically,
            banking sector and natural monopoly reform, as well as
            fiscal issues relating to the sustainability of the
            financial stabilization program of tax reforms, budget
            management, and intergovernmental fiscal relations. The SAL
            provides a crucial vehicle for intensive technical support
            to the government both in the detailed design and in the
            implementation of measures under the program. The lack of
            such support in 1996 was an important reason for pervasive
            implementation problems on the structural side of the EFF.
